member.summary: Performs a build operation.

The to use for this build operation.

The to use for this build operation.
The key of the object to build.

member.returns: The built object.

member.summary: Add a new object to this list.
member.param: Object to add.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Practices.ObjectBuilder2.IRecoveryStack.ExecuteRecovery
member.summary: Execute the method of everything in the recovery list. Recoveries will execute in the opposite order of add - it's a stack.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Practices.ObjectBuilder2.IRecoveryStack.Count
member.summary: Return the number of recovery objects currently in the stack.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Practices.ObjectBuilder2.IRequiresRecovery
member.summary: This interface provides a hook for the builder context to implement error recovery when a builder strategy throws an exception. Since we can't get try/finally blocks onto the call stack for later stages in the chain, we instead add these objects to the context. If there's an exception, all the current IRequiresRecovery instances will have their Recover methods called.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Practices.ObjectBuilder2.IRequiresRecovery.Recover
member.summary: A method that does whatever is needed to clean up as part of cleaning up after an exception.
member.remarks: Don't do anything that could throw in this method, it will cause later recover operations to get skipped and play real havok with the stack trace.

member.summary: Represents a strategy in the 's chain of responsibility. Strategies are required to support both BuildUp and TearDown. Although you can implement this interface directly, you may also choose to use as the base class for your strategies, as this class provides useful helper methods and makes support BuildUp and TearDown optional.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Practices.ObjectBuilder2.CreationStrategy
member.summary: Represents a strategy which creates objects.

remarks.para: This strategy looks for policies in the context registered under the interface type . If it cannot find a policy on how to create the object, it will select the first constructor that returns from reflection, and re-runs the chain to create all the objects required to fulfill the constructor's parameters.

If the Build method is passed an object via the existing parameter, then it will do nothing (since the object already exists). This allows this strategy to be in the chain when running dependency injection on existing objects, without fear that it will attempt to re-create the object.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Practices.ObjectBuilder2.IReadableLocator
member.summary: Represents a locator that can be read from.

remarks.para: A locator is a dictionary of keys to values, but it keeps the values with weak references, so that locating an object does not keep it alive. If you want to keep the object alive too, you should consider using an .

Locators have a built-in concept of hierarchy, so you can ask questions of a locator and tell it whether to return results from the current locator only, or whether to ask the parent locator when local lookups fail.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Practices.ObjectBuilder2.SingletonStrategy
member.summary: Implementation of which allows objects to be singletons.
member.remarks: This strategy looks for policies in the context registered under the interface type . It uses the locator in the build context to rememeber singleton objects, and the lifetime container contained in the locator to ensure they are not garbage collected. Upon the second request for an object, it will short-circuit the strategy chain and return the singleton instance (and will not re-inject the object).
